dataset.title: US-Hungary Grassland Biodiversity (cross-site project): 4x4 m Sample Plot Data (1996-1997)

address.deliveryPoint: Agriculture Builiding, University College Dublin Belfield

section.para: Plant cover estimates were collected from Bouteloua grasslands at 3 different LTER (SGS, SEV, JRN) sites in summer of 1996/1997. The purpose of the data collection was to compare species composition and diversity between LTER sites and sandy grassland sites in Hungary.

para.literalLayout: Additional Site InformationSite 1Site Name: SGS LTER: Central Plains Experimental Range, Pasture 15Site Location: SE quadrant of Pasture 15Site Coordinates: 40.8o N, 104.8o WSite Size: 30 quadrat pairs within a 400 m x 800 m area (the size of the area was reduced from the standard 400 m x 1200 m, because of the different grazing history of the other parts of the pasture.Site Landform: undulating plain, only hillsides and hilltops were sampledSite Elevation: 1650 m ASLSite Soil: sandy loamSite Vegetation: Blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis) dominated shortgrass steppe, with Buchloe dactyloides, Opuntia polyacantha and Artemisia frigidaSite History: long-term moderately grazedSite 2Site Name: SEV LTER: McKenzie Flats, between Deep Well and Five PointsSite Location: East of the road going from Deep Well to Five Points about 100 m from the road.Site Coordinates: 34.5o N, 106.9o WSite Size: 40 quadrat pairs in 400 x 1200 m areaSite Landform: PlainSite Elevation: 1650 m ASLSite Soil: Sand: 75% Silt: 11% Clay: 14% Rocks ( more than2mm): 1% (0-20 cm depth); sandy loam (measurements based on samples by Gy. Kroel-Dulay)Site Vegetation: Blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis) and Black grama (Bouteloua eriopoda) dominated grasslandsSite History: Livestock excluded since 1973Site 3Site Name: JRN LTER: Chihuahuan Desert Rangeland Research Center, Pasture 15Site Location: Middle of Pasture 15 running E-W (GPS data available from B. Nolen)Site Coordinates: 32.5o N, 106.8o WSite Size: 34 quadrat pairs within a 400 m x 1200 m areaSite Landform: PlainSite Elevation: 1350 m ASLSite Soil: Sand: 82% Silt: 10% Clay: 8% (0-20cm depth); loamy sand (based on three 0-30 cm samples taken from the middle of the 50 ha plot)Site Vegetation: Black grama (Bouteloua eriopoda) grassland, with mesquite (Prosopis glandulosa) shrubsSite History: Lightly grazed year roundStudy Affiliations Colorado State University, Institute of Ecology and Botany of the Hungarian Academy of SciencesNotes about the data (anomalies, missing sampling intervals, etc.): SEV was sampled Aug/Sept 1996, Jornada Aug 1996, and CPER June - early July 1997. This dataset is associated with 1x1m plots nested inside the 4x4m plots, and some small scale samples (5x5 cm). Small cover values were recorded as 'Trace' in the field and translated into 0.01 in the data. Unknown Species are named Species a, b, c, etc. and as precise a description of the lifeform as possible is given in parentheses. Total cover, Standing dead/litter and Bare were not estimated at the SGS as these estimates seemed rather arbitrary at the other sites. Overlap between the canopy of different plants is minimal.

This dataset is released to the public and may be freely downloaded. Please keep the designated Contact person informed of any plans to use the dataset. Consultation or collaboration with the original investigators is strongly encouraged. Publications and data products that make use of the dataset must include proper acknowledgement of the Sevilleta LTER. Datasets must be cited as in the example below.
Muldavin, E. 2004. Sevilleta LTER Fertilizer NPP Study Dataset. Albuquerque, NM: Sevilleta Long Term Ecological Research Site Database: SEV155. (Date of download)
A copy of any publications using these data must be supplied to the Sevilleta LTER Information Manager.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Location: McKenzie Flats is located within the northeastern section of the Sevilleta NWR, encompassing an area from Black Butte south to Palo Duro Canyon and east to the Los Pinos.Landform: McKenzie Flats is a broad, nearly flat grassland plain between the Los Pinos Mountains and the breaks on the east side of the Rio Grande., Geology: Deep (20,000 ft) alluvial and aeolian deposits., Soils: Turney Series: fine-loamy, mixed, thermic Typic Calciorthids. Berino Series: fine-loamy, mixed, thermic Typic Haplargids., Hydrology: Surface water only during rain events, no arroyos. Run-on plain for Los Pinos Mountains., Vegetation: The terrain is generally a mixed-species desert grassland, dominated by black grama (Bouteloua eriopoda), blue grama (B. gracilis), sand muhly (Muhlenbergia arenicola), various drop seeds and sacatons (Sporobolus spp.), purple three-awn (Aristida purpurea), and burrow grass (Scleropogon brevifolia). Shrubs are common in the area around Five Points, including creosote bush (Larrea tridentata) and snakeweed (Gutierrezia sarothrae)., Climate: Long-term mean annual precipitation is 243 mm, about 60% of which occurs during the summer. Long-term mean monthly temperatures for January and July are 1.5 degrees C and 25.1 degrees C, respectively., History: McKenzie Flats encompasses an area of approximately 50 square miles and was one of the primary livestock grazing areas within what is now the Sevilleta NWR. Cattle have been excluded from the site since 1974-76. The ranch headquarters buildings and corrals were located at the junction of Legs C and D of the coyote survey. , siteid: 25

para.literalLayout: 8/5/2003 - File created from Excel metadata template submitted by Tamara Hochstrasser. -- KLVStatus Data Update: August 5, 2003Status Archival Date: August 5, 2003Status Metadata Update: August 5, 2003Status Verification: August 5, 2003

address.deliveryPoint: Box 30003, MSC 3JER New Mexico State University Ecosystems Center

para.literalLayout: Data Collection Data are from random locations in a 50 ha plot. The random points were located using coordinates (generated based on random numbers in Excel) and a 10 x 10 m grid across the whole study area that was marked with pin flags using a theodolite and a tape. Random points on disturbances (non-Bouteloua dominated spots) were discarded. At each random point we layed out two 4 m x 4 m quadrats at a 8 m distance from each other (pointing in a random direction) and estimated the cover of all species in them. This sampling design was chosen to be able to do spatial analyses on the data, such as analyses using geo-statistical methods.

SEV was sampled Aug/Sept 1996, Jornada Aug 1996, and CPER June - early July 1997. This dataset is associated with 1x1m plots nested inside the 4x4m plots, and some small scale samples (5x5 cm). Small cover values were recorded as 'Trace' in the field and translated into 0.01 in the data. Unknown Species are named Species a, b, c, etc. and as precise a description of the lifeform as possible is given in parentheses. Total cover, Standing dead/litter and Bare were not estimated at the SGS as these estimates seemed rather arbitrary at the other sites. Overlap between the canopy of different plants is minimal.

methodStep.instrumentation: Study Instrumentation: Theodolite, Tape, String and Nails

para.literalLayout: Data introduction verified by Tamara Hochstrasser and Gyorgy Kroel-Dulay (comparison with field notebooks)
